description: Nikola Petrak, leveraging his legacy Council credentials and influence, authorizes a citywide lockdown on all Memory Markets, instructing district administrators to seal drop-boxes and restrict access to story-sharing gatherings. Official rationale highlights the need to preserve public order amid BCI instability.

City security teams sweep through Halden Zones, closing physical Memory Market venues and erasing digital story feeds wherever possible. Some markets move underground, and pockets of resistance quietly form in response to the crackdown.

Rada and citizen organizers launch the 'Memory Cascade,' encouraging mass deposit of handwritten diaries, testimonies, and stories in new, improvised drop-sites across districts, defying the Council’s restrictions.

The surge of uncensored memory submissions overloads the BCI's compliance scoring functions, freezing updates and disrupting automated service allocation. Residents notice housing, jobs, and access remain unchanged, sparking widespread disbelief and more open defiance of system controls.

With the BCI’s authority functionally collapsed, neighbors form self-organized systems for basic needs and conflict resolution. The city enters an uncertain period of improvisation, cooperation, and sporadic unrest—as citizen memory overpowers centralized control.
